title: ImmigrationLaw,Policy&ConstRts
description: Immigration Law, Policy and Constitutional Rights (20547). 3 units. This introductory survey course will provide a foundation in the basics of the immigration system, explore the constitutional principles governing the regulation of non-citizens, examine some key topical issues concerning immigration law and immigrants' rights, and consider the normative values informing contemporary policies toward documented and undocumented immigrants. The course will draw on the instructorâ€™s involvement in many contemporary issues and his experience litigating on behalf of the constitutional and civil rights cases on behalf of non-citizens. Among current issues likely to be covered are: detention of immigrants; state and local immigration regulation; discrimination on the basis of citizenship in employment and public benefits; the intersection of criminal and immigration law; federal enforcement practices and discretion; access to the courts and habeas corpus for non-citizens; labor and workplace protections; and proposals for legislative and administrative reform. We will have occasional guest speakers. Students should anticipate some classes being re-scheduled during the semester. No prior course or background in immigration law is expected. Self-scheduled examination. L. Guttentag.
